title: Catholic group spent millions on app data that tracked gay priests

last_post.content:
This is a "holy shit" story with an emphasis on the holy: https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2023/03/09/catholics-gay-priests-grindr-data-bishops/

To out priests using Grindr, a conservative group spent "millions of dollars" on mobile app tracking data.

This whole saga has been one of the most illuminating case studies in the privacy harms that can come from "aggregated" and "de-identified" data being freely sold in the marketplace.

title: Police are getting help from social media sites to prosecute people for abortion

last_post.content:
Meta handed over a user’s messages about accessing abortion medication to law enforcement. This has been happening since before Roe was overturned.

https://www.businessinsider.com/police-getting-help-social-media-to-prosecute-people-seeking-abortions-2023-2

title: https://bird.makeup

last_post.content: Thanks to @foreverandaday for making it known the existence of https://bird.makeup, a fork of BirdsiteLIVE that uses the same back-end as Nitter(https://github.com/zedeus/nitter), which uses the hidden Twitter API. We do not wish to bypass the Twitter-allowed usage guidelines and have no guarantee Twitter will not axe hidden API access with tooling in the future, so if you would like to migrate to https://bird.makeup, which may last past the Feb 9 cut.

title: Hachette v. Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The lawsuit we're fighting isn’t just about the Internet Archive. It will determine the future of all libraries & their patrons, including those with print disabilities. #Accesstoknowledge for diverse communities will be impacted 🌍

Over the next 20 days until we go to court, we’ll be giving you 20 reasons to care about this lawsuit. We can’t wait to introduce you to the teachers, doctors, journalists & many more who rely on our lending library #EmpoweringLibraries https://www.eff.org/cases/hachette-v-internet-archive

title: Upwelling: Combining real-time collaboration with version control for writers.

last_post.content:
It was an immense privilege to work with the very fine folks at Ink & Switch on Upwelling, an exploration of writer-focused collaboration tools: https://www.inkandswitch.com/upwelling/

Collaboration tools for software developers (git, etc) have been deeply explored and are rich in diversity and features. Writers' tools: not so much. With Upwelling, we leaned into recent advances in CRDTs to experiment with possible UX patterns for collaboration on prose.

title: Fed up and burnt out: ‘quiet quitting’ hits academia

last_post.content:
75% of scientists are burned out and pulling back on conferences, peer review, committee membership, etc https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00633-w

When scientists set boundaries, it not only improves their own personal well-being, but also creates norms that limits are acceptable and healthy

title: 'Horribly Unethical': Startup Experimented on Suicidal Teens on Social Media With Chatbot

last_post.content:
"I have not in recent years seen a study so callously asleep at the ethical wheel. Dealing with suicidal persons in this way is inexcusable."

I knew Morris as a PhD student, and I'm sure this wasn't his intent. But as someone who studies & creates ethics procedures for online experiments, I completely agree with the critiques of this non-consented mental health study. Well-intentioned ignorance is a very dangerous thing.

https://www.vice.com/en/article/5d9m3a/horribly-unethical-startup-experimented-on-suicidal-teens-on-facebook-tumblr-with-chatbot

title: Samsung "space zoom" moon shots are fake, and here is the proof

last_post.content:
Samsung is replacing actual pictures you take of the moon with a fake AI version that is crystal clear.

This is pretty terrifying. The phone software can identify objects in pictures and replace them.

How long until they're replacing the content of billboards in the backgrounds of your pictures with whoever pays for it? What if they decide you can't record encounters with the police, and it automatically blurs the face of the police?
https://www.reddit.com/r/Android/comments/11nzrb0/samsung_space_zoom_moon_shots_are_fake_and_here/

title: GitHub - rmcelreath/stat_rethinking_2023: Statistical Rethinking Course for Jan-Mar 2023

last_post.content:
The 2023 edition of my long-running anti-establishment art-science-fusion code-therapy smooth-baritone causal inference & Bayesian data analysis course is complete. 20 lectures, from the basics of causal inference & Bayesian updating to mixed models & Gaussian processes.

Lecture recordings, slides, homework sets and solutions are all listed here. Take it at your own pace. First half is a solid course in regression and causal inference. Second half turns it up to 11. https://github.com/rmcelreath/stat_rethinking_2023#calendar--topical-outline

last_post.content:

@natematias has a detailed thread here https://social.coop/@natematias/109990388176345899

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020 period, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: https://ramblingreaders.org

last_post.content: Do you know there's a #fediverse alternative to Amazon-owned #Goodreads? #BookWyrm is a social network for tracking your reading, writing reviews, and discovering what to read next. You can follow and interact with users on different #BookWyrm instances and on #Mastodon. You can import from a Goodreads CSV export. You can create private shelves and curated lists. Join us at https://ramblingreaders.org or choose one of the other instances available #books #reading  #bookstodon @bookstodon

"This experience has been instructive for me. Once you start thinking on timescales of 5-10 years, communities built on proprietary software just don’t pass muster. title: Israeli troops fired into group of Palestinian civilians in Nablus

last_post.content: “The Post collected more than 1,000 photos and geospatial data of the site. This data was processed in photogrammetry software Metashape and exported as a scaled 3D mesh. The Post then used perspective plotting tools alongside available location and camera lens metadata from the collected photographs and videos to add virtual cameras into the scene, matching the perspective of key visuals from different angles, and assisting in the accurate modeling of the site.” https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/interactive/2023/palestine-shooting-nablus-videos/

title: Silicon Valley Bank Used Former McCarthy Staffers to Weaken Regulations, Lobby FDIC

last_post.content:
SVB lobbyists, many of whom had worked for prominent political figures like Bill Clinton, Kevin McCarthy, and Jay Inslee, convinced Congress to "exempt banks the size of Silicon Valley Bank from more stringent regulations, including stress tests aimed at uncovering the type of weaknesses that led to the bank’s implosion Friday."

This is what political corruption looks like.

SVB President Greg Becker also pushed for exemptions, and should be held liable, IMO.

https://theintercept.com/2023/03/11/silicon-valley-bank-used-former-mccarthy-staffers-to-weaken-regulations-lobby-fdic/

title: Mosaic Virus, 2019 — Anna Ridler

last_post.content:
An interesting example in the talk about the difference between models built on top of pirated content and artwork built with original content is Anna Ridler's Mosaic Virus.

title: Chapter 12 Bias detection | Improving Your Statistical Inferences

last_post.content: Want to learn about p-curve analysis? My textbook chapter on 'bias detection' has a section on p-value meta-analysis: https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/bias.html#p-value-meta-analysis It will give you a complete overview of what these tests can and can not do.

Warnung: Dieser Artikel kann ein Life-Changer sein, eine Ex-Kollegin von mir ist wegen dieser Lektüre nach dem Philosophie-Bachelor auf einen Informatik-Master gewechselt. #dhd2023

title: Pull missing responses into Mastodon - blog.thms.uk

last_post.content:
One problem with being on a small instance is that you generally don't see all the replies to posts, you only get the ones that make it to your server via the magic of federation.

The fix has been mastodon_get_replies. It's a script that scans your home timeline periodically and loads in all of the replies to posts that you might otherwise not have seen. It can also backfill past posts from people you follow! It's mostly eliminated the missing posts problem

https://blog.thms.uk/2023/03/pull-missing-responses-into-mastodon

title: Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022)

last_post.content:
Walter's review of Everything Everywhere All at Once from April last year was devastating in its honesty and vulnerability, about what it's like to be a child of immigrant Chinese. My life has been so very different from his, and yet so very much the same.

https://www.filmfreakcentral.net/ffc/2022/03/everything-everywhere-all-at-once-1.html

His review was so raw and honest about the Asian immigrant experience that Daniel Kwan called it out at the time: https://twitter.com/dunkwun/status/1509934007462821888

title: NY Met to let French make 3D copies of two 16th-century sculptures

last_post.content:
Two cheers for this project to make #3D laser scans of two #PublicDomain #sculptures & create duplicates for display in their original location.
https://phys.org/news/2023-02-ny-met-french-3d-16th-century.html

PS: Would be better to make the digital scans #OpenAccess & let anyone make copies of any size or use them for remote viewing w/ zooming & 3D rotation. It's not a new idea & many #museums already do it. Here are some examples from the Open Access Tracking Project (@oatp, #oatp).
http://tagteam.harvard.edu/hubs/oatp/tag/oa.3d

#CulturalHeritage #GLAM

title: How to get your At-Home Over-The-Counter COVID-19 Test for Free | CMS

last_post.content:
In the US, the #COVID public health emergency may lapse on May 11. That means… funding for stuff you now get for #free will disappear.

If you have insurance, your insurance is required to reimburse you for 8 #tests per insured person per calendar month.

E.g., 2 adults + 2 kids = 32 tests (16 2-packs) per month

So… you can still get 3 months’ worth FREE IF you place an order in March, then in April, then in May (before the 11th!).

https://www.cms.gov/how-to-get-your-at-home-OTC-COVID-19-test-for-free

#publicHealth #reminder
